oai_dc:dc.dc:format: 110 leaves of plates : col. ill. ; 16 x 23 cm.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: by Edward Lear ; from the tenth London edition ; with many new pictures and verses.
"From the tenth London edition ; with many new pictures and verses".
Printed on one side of leaf only; leaf <41> misnumbered 4.
James Miller, bookseller, moved to 779 Broadway in 1877 and remained there until his death in 1883.

Conduct of life--Juvenile poetry
Children--Conduct of life--Juvenile poetry
Stories in rhyme

Book of nonsense
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward , 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: enk: Frederick Warne and Co., Bedford Street, Strand.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections and Archives, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: By Edward Lear.
Cover title: A book of nonsense / by Edwd. Lear ; [at top left] 110 coloured illustrations.

First date based on inclusion of Armstrong's name in Scribner imprints from 1872 to 1878. Second date conjectural, based on cover title: covers of almost certainly later 1870s editions read "Lear's book of nonsense ..."

Printed on outer forme only, 2 or 3 sets of limericks and ill. per leaf in text, totalling 110 on 52 leaves, plus 2 on frontispiece and 1 on t.p. ; blank leaves inserted between facing printed leaves.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Edwin Prince, 1841
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: In this letter, written to Edwin Prince on August 20, 1841, Edward Lear inquires after John Gould on the death of Gould's wife. Lear illustrated Gould's famous ornithological work. The letter is written from Knowsley Hall, seat of the Earl of Derby. It was for Derby's children that Lear wrote, The Book of Nonsense, published in 1846.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knowsley Hall (England)--History--19th century
Gould, John 1804-1881
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Henry Bruce, August 11, 1877
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Has sent the painting of the Kinchinjunga. Asks them not to state the price to anyone, for he would charge others more. Requests payment of the balance. May not return to England, for he has no family and few remaining friends. Speaks of various acquaintances.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: Stratton, Micheldever Station
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Henry Bruce, August 23, 1877
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Lear is delighted that the painting of the Kinchinjunga pleases. Has been told that he cannot consider himself a painter since he paints on commission and is unknown to the public.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: 8 Duchess Street. Portland Place
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Henry Bruce, December 31, 1883
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: Villa Tennyson, Sanremo, Italia
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Sends New Year greetings. Is 72 but continues working. Prefers large subjects as less trying to the eyes. Sends his works to Foord's in Wardour Street for sale. The two sons of his old servant now care for him. Quotes a portion of "Mrs. Jayphar's Wisdom."
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Henry Bruce, July 3, 1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: 15 Stratford Place, Oxford Street, W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Playfully accuses Bruce of avoiding him.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Henry Bruce, July 31, 1863
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: 15 Stratford Place, Oxford Street, W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Feels remorse at not having called on Mrs. Bruce. Has been hoping to get their children to his house. Has been making a small copy of a painting for "little Willie" Beadon, whose father lived at No. 9, opposite. Is going to Hastings. Refers to Napier's writings on Cephalonica. Lear will be in London in September and Bruce may select from numerous paintings. Refers to "Ionian Judge" political controversy. Hears Bruce is well liked as Under Secretary.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Henry Bruce, June 6, 1875
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Lear's friend, Penry Williams, has become concerned about the fate of correspondence he retains. Lear asks if Lord Aberdare would agree to keep it in case anyone should wish to prepare a memoir of Williams. Lear fears that he may forget to address the title his old friends now elevated to the peerage. He has completed Lord and Lady Aberdare's paintings of Smila and Benares. Will do Lord Aberdare's Kinchinjunga next winter.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: Villa Emily, Sanremo
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Henry Bruce, November 24, 1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: Hotel Danieli, Venice, Italy
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Compliments Bruce on his Ministry and describes his happy reaction to the appointment of Chichester Fortescue to the Irish Secretaryship. Hopes for the rise of T. G. Baring. Has been sketching but weather is foggy. He fears asthma. His servant George is ill at Corfu.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Henry Bruce, October 18, 1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: 15 Stratford Place, Oxford Street, W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Quarantines have changed his travel plans. After painting view of Jerusalem and Mt. Olympus, Lear will head south. Holman Hunt is to marry in December and go to Palestine. References to numerous social visits, including one to Tennyson.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Henry Bruce, September 11, 1872
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Regrets he will not be able to visit, for all his time is taken up. Acknowledges a commission for a painting to be executed in India.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: 6 Chandos Street, Cavendish Square, W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Henry Bruce, September 25, 1884
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Acknowledges the purchase of his paintings for pounds 31.8.0. Is surprised that Millais receives such prices for works that require much less labor than Lear's. Considers new publications and republications. Refers to Richard Doyle as "a wonderfully beautiful artist." Speaks of his work on 200 illustrations for Tennyson.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: Villa Tennyson, Sanremo
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Henry Bruce, September 26, 1875
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Has ordered a six-foot canvas to be sent to Sanremo for the painting of the Kinchinjunga. Stays at Franklin Lushington's on the way to Folkstone.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: Riverhead Vicarage, 7 Okes [sic]
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Henry Bruce, September 8, 1866
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: 15 Stratford Place, Oxford Street, W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Inquires about the opportunities for an old friend's son, who has been thrown out of work by recent economic conditions. Refers to the death of Thomas George Baring's father; the son will now be Lord Northbrook. Lear's friend Penry Williams thinks of settling in London. Lear has accidentally burned a canvas. Sir Henry Storks has asked Lear to go to Malta with him. References to Cardinal Manning and to Holman Hunt.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Henry Bruce, undated
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Concerns establishing a time for a visit with Bruce. Refers to the William Beadons.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: 16 Upper Seymour Street, Portman Square

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Henry Bruce, undated
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Sorry to have missed him. Mentions T. G. Baring, E. Drummond, Mr. Helps, Stephen Carr, and Spenser Robinson. Gives an anecdote of a school inspector.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Nora Bruce, April 15, 1868-May 7, 1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: On a sheet begun at Cannes, 15 April 1868. Lear is miserable in Cannes and decided to leave. Since he could not go to Palestine as planned, he went to Corsica to paint. However, wet weather and fever make him think of returning to Nice and England.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: Ajaccio, Corsica
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Nora Bruce, April 25, 1875
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Has failed to reply to her because of his eyesight and guests. Has seen Oliver Jones, Lord Digby and Lord Wyatt. Failed earlier to congratulate her daughter, Margaret Richmond, on the birth of a son. Is preparing landscape sketches for both Lord and Lady Aberdare. Plans another for Lord Aberdare. Expects to be in London in June. Requires a big room to exhibit his paintings. His servant's wife has died.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: Villa Emily, Sanremo
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Nora Bruce, December 24, 1870
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Mrs. W. Napier has not come. Refers to recent publication of his Nonsense Songs and Stories. His new rooms are too wet to occupy. The war has made it difficult to sell paintings. Becomes increasingly indifferent as he grows older. Asks after Mrs. W. Beadon, her children and others.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: San Remo, Italia
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Nora Bruce, February 13, 1875
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: He has returned from India. Hears that she has twin grandchildren. Will begin a painting for her.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: Villa Emily, Sanremo
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Nora Bruce, February 26, 1877
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Is glad that Lord Aberdare was not seriously hurt. Received General, Mrs. and Miss McMurdo last Thursday. His servant George is very ill. Would Lord Aberdare be willing to make an advanced payment on his painting?
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: Villa Emily, Sanremo
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Nora Bruce, January 10, 1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: 61 Promenade des Anglais, Nice, France
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Is reading a biography of her father, William Napier. Wishes to read Napier's account of the Peninsular War and other writings. Asks after her uncle, who wrote a history of Florence. Has walked to Genoa and back preparing drawings. Asks after Mrs. W. F. Beadon and child. Objects to social swells at Nice.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Nora Bruce, November 25, 1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: About Henry Bruce's loss of an election for Parliament. Will finish 50 drawings in three more days.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: 15 Stratford Place, Oxford Street, W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Edward Lear to Nora Bruce, October 7, 1877
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward, 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Wishes to hear from them and to know how they like the Kinchinjunga. Speaks of his new servant's comical diction. Sends copies of his new list of paintings (not present). Has visited his old servant at Corfu.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Place of publication: Villa Emily, Sanremo
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Facsimile of A nonsense alphabet
A nonsense alphabet
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lear, Edward , 1812-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: enk: F. Warne
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections and Archives, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: drawn and written by Edward Lear.
Published for the first time from ms. drawings and text executed by Lear about 1849; cf. "Publishers' note".
"1,000 copies only have been printed and no further issue will be made. This copy is number 690."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Nonsense verses
